metadata.title: Additive free, room temperature direct homogeneous catalytic carbon dioxide hydrogenation in aqueous solution using an iron(II) phosphine catalyst

Priority Communication Additive free, room temperature direct homogeneous catalytic carbon dioxide hydrogenation in aqueous solution using an iron(II) phosphine catalyst Mickael Montandon-Clerc Gábor Laurenczy ⁎ Institut des Sciences et Ingénierie Chimiques, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland Institut des Sciences et Ingénierie Chimiques École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) CH-1015 Lausanne Switzerland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The negative consequences of the global warming require an important reduction of CO2 emission; and the valorization of the carbon dioxide, its transformation into useful chemicals is essential. We present here our studies on the direct CO2 hydrogenation reaction, yielding formic acid. In water, for the first time, an Fe(II) catalyst using meta-trisulfonated-tris[2-(diphenyl-phosphino)-ethyl]phosphine (PP3TS) ligand, has been found active in CO2 reduction. In homogeneous catalytic reactions, without any additives, at room temperature, under hydrogen and carbon dioxide gas pressures up to 0.5 M of formic acid is obtained, in acidic aqueous solutions. The same catalyst is active also in the reverse reaction, under different reaction conditions, i.e. at low pressure and high temperature. The CO2 reduction and formic acid dehydrogenation catalytic cycle has been repeated several times; without deactivation of the catalyst, it is not sensitive to oxygen/air. The Fe(II)-PP3TS complex could be a suitable catalyst in a chemical hydrogen storage/delivery system. Keywords Carbon dioxid hydrogenation Iron(II) catalyst Direct CO2 reduction Aqueous solution Formic acid Formic acid dehydrogenation Hydrogen storage 1 Introduction Global warming and all the consequences, climate changes are the reality today. There is a consensus among the majority of scientists concerning the cause: augmentation of CO2 level in the atmosphere (over 400 ppm today versus 345 thirty five years ago) [1]. CO2 is a greenhouse gas, the heat is conserved at the surface of Earth. However, this is not the only issue, with more CO2 in the atmosphere, the pH of the sea water will decrease, leading to the acidification of the oceans [2]. All these changes could have tremendous repercussions on the ecosystem of our planet. In response, both politicians and scientists should make effort to limit the carbon dioxide emission. The main source of the CO2 emission is the fossil fuel combustion. Increasing utilization of the renewable energy sources (hydroelectric, geothermic, wind and solar energy) is the first step toward the reduction of CO2 production. An interesting, although minor contribution would be to use CO2 in chemical syntheses. CO2 can be used/is used as a C1 building block for useful molecules (e.g. urea, salicylic acid, cyclic carbonates, epoxides, formaldehyde, etc) [3,4]. Nature uses CO2 as carbon source for the living organisms. CO2 can be also used as hydrogen vector, to store chemically the H2 gas, an elegant contribution of CO2 utilization. Hydrogen is one of the most promising energy carriers. It has high gravimetric energy density and clean combustion pathways, but it is difficult to store it. Conventional hydrogen storage methods, like high pressure tanks and liquefaction, have safety and cost issues [5]. Therefore, the chemical hydrogen storage, the catalytic reduction of CO2 into formic acid, into methanol or into other useful chemicals have both the advantage of storing hydrogen and adding value to carbon dioxide. Formic acid (FA) has recently drawn attention in H2 storage because its several advantages: It is liquid at room temperature with a volumetric hydrogen storage capacity of 53 g/L (it has a gravimetric hydrogen content of 4.4 wt%). FA has low toxicity and it is non-flammable below 85 vol% concentration (diluted with water), it is a good candidate for hydrogen storage [6,7]. Since 2006, a large number of studies dealt with the selective FA dehydrogenation [8,9]. A wide variety of metals and ligands have been used as catalysts for homogeneous and heterogeneous formic acid splitting into H2 and CO2, using either noble or non-noble metals, in a wide selection of solvents, reviewed recently [10]. The opposite reaction, the direct carbon dioxide hydrogenation to FA has got special attention as well, a large number of catalysts have been reported for the reduction of CO2 [10]. However, in the overwhelming majority of the cases, this reduction has been carried out in the presence of a base and/or use carbonate and bicarbonate substrates instead of CO2 gas. Indeed, CO2 has a high thermodynamic stability; in gas phase it cannot be directly hydrogenated to FA (the Gibbs free energy for this reaction, Δ G ° is positive, +33 KJ/mole). In basic aqueous solutions, CO2 is transformed into bicarbonates ( HC O 3 - ) and carbonates ( C O 3 2 - ), and these substrates can be reduced directly, the Gibbs free energy change then will be negative (around –35 KJ/mole), hence favorable for the reaction [11]. Nevertheless, there are only a few reports for the direct reduction of CO2 in acidic solutions, acidic conditions [10]. All these studies use, however, noble metal based catalysts and to the best of our knowledge there is no report for direct, homogeneous CO2 hydrogenation, using a first row transition metal (non-noble metal) catalyst, in water. Combining both hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions, applying a cheap iron(II) complex could lead to the development of an affordable, battery-like energy/hydrogen storage system. This system could have a potential application in mobile energy supply. 2 Results Recently we have studied the homogeneous formic acid dehydrogenation reaction with the Fe(II)-PP3TS catalyst [12]. Now we have investigated the direct reduction of CO2 in aqueous solution (that is in acidic medium), using the same iron(II) complex. When we have pressurized with hydrogen and carbon dioxide the aqueous solution of Fe(BF4)2; in presence of meta-trisulfonated-tris[2-(diphenylphosphino)ethyl]phosphine sodium salt (PP3TS – Fig. 1 ); we could detect the formation of formic acid in the reaction mixture, even at room temperature. 10 mm high pressure sapphire NMR tubes were used to carry out these reactions, a mixing device was applied to solubilize H2 and CO2, to reach always the saturation concentrations. FA concentrations were measured in situ under pressure by quantitative 1H and 13C NMR (see Experimental). When we have pressurized an aqueous solution of Fe(BF4)2 (0.05 M) and PP3TS (0.05 M) with 50 bar of H2 and 50 bar of CO2 in a 10 mm sapphire NMR tube; heated this tube to 50 °C and mixed it for several hours, more than 0.1 M formic acid solution was detected by 1H and 13C NMR in the solution. We have investigated the effect of the catalyst concentration on the formic acid production/yield, and the iron(II) to phosphine ligand ratio, using Fe(BF4)2 salts as catalyst precursors. Pressure (50 bar H2 and 50 bar CO2) and temperature (25 °C) were kept constant during the whole reaction (generally 60 h – checking several times the formic acid concentration, verifying to arrive to equilibria), Table 1 . The ratio of the iron salt with respect to the ligand was kept constant while varying the concentration of the catalyst complex. The catalyst concentration does not influence the formic acid yield significantly (Table 1), indicating that the limiting factor for the conversion is thermodynamic. It should be the hydrogen and CO2 equilibrium concentration under pressure in water. The catalyst concentration certainly influences the reaction rate. The reaction requires gas solubilization under pressure (CO2 and H2), it is necessity to have an intensive mixing. The quantitative NMR technique gave the only possibility for FA concentration determination in situ, under pressure (time-consuming measurements, long acquisitions). For these reasons we were not able to do precise kinetic analysis for this reaction. We are working on to find a suitable experimental setup to collect detailed kinetic information on this reaction. In Table 2 the results concerning the effect of the ligand to iron(II) ratio has been shown. The ratio of the iron salt with respect to the ligand was varied between 2:1 and 1:3. Different iron salt were tested as precursors (FeCl2, Fe(BF4)2 and (NH4)2Fe(SO4)2. A poisoning effect has occurred when FeCl2 was used (at high chloride concentrations the formation of chloride bridged dimers is possible), the catalytic activity of this precursor were lower. Using half equivalent of PP3TS ligand could lead to bimetallic complex formation, with reduced catalytic activity. In case of large PP3TS ligand excess, the formation of the ML2, ML3 type complexes could reduce the available active coordination sites around the Fe(II) ion. The excess of the PP3TS ligand blocks the access of the substrate to the iron(II) cation, avoiding catalytic reduction. As it is can be seen from variation of the chemical shift of the 31P signal of the tris-ethylene linked P atom in meta-trisulfonated-tris[2-(diphenylphosphino)ethyl]phosphine (PP3TS) at acidic and neutral solutions, this P atom can be protonated (Fig. 2 a), while the other PPh2 type P atoms not, in the studied pH range. Indeed, the 31P NMR peak, corresponding to the triethylenephosphine bridgehead phosphorus, it was shifted from −20 ppm to 15 ppm under acidic conditions with decreasing pH, while the chemical shift of the signal corresponding to PPh2 phosphorus atoms practically does not change. From the 31P NMR shifts it was possible to calculate the pKa of the tris-ethylene-P phosphine, being pKa = 4.73 (Fig. 2b) The effect of CO2 and H2 pressure on the formic acid yield, as well as the consequence of the changing the proportion of CO2 to H2 pressures have been also investigated (Table 3 ). The highest FA concentration was obtained using 100 bar of H2 and 50 bar of CO2. Higher concentrations of formic acid were obtained using higher hydrogen and carbon dioxide pressures (higher dissolved hydrogen and CO2 concentrations are increasing the FA yield – Le Chatelier-Braun principle). The measurements under 150 bars total pressure were carried out in an autoclave (these sapphire NMR tubes can be used in up to 100 bar total pressure). The direct carbon dioxide hydrogenation is an exothermic reaction, the temperature influences the produced formic acid quantity, concentration. As this reduction is exothermic, increasing temperature decreases the FA yield (Table 4 ). From the data collected in Table 4, the enthalpy of the carbon dioxide hydrogenation reaction can be determined (Fig. 3 ). If we consider that Δ r G ° = - RTln ( K ) and that Δ r G ° = Δ H - T Δ S , with K = FA [ H 2 ] [ C O 2 ] , one can plot ln [ FA ] vs 1 / T , where Δ r H R will be the slope. The slope being 3163.1; one can find Δ r H = - 26.29 kJ / K ∙ mol for this reaction under our conditions. Thermodynamic considerations: Considering that the Gibbs free energy , Δ rG ° = - RTln ( K t h erm ) , that K t h erm = HCOOH [ H 2 ] [ C O 2 ] , rearranging for HCOOH = H 2 C O 2 exp - Δ G RT . With Δ rG ° = 4 KJ mol for formic acid, R = 0.008314 L ∙ Bar K ∙ mol , T = 298 K at room temperature, H 2 = 0.08 M (estimated using Henry’s law with Kh = 1279.31 L ∙ atm/mol [13] and C O 2 = 1.25 M [14] at 50 bar, one can calculate a maximum formic acid yield around of 0.5 M under these specific conditions. As it has been shown previously, (1) can catalyze efficiently the formic acid dehydrogenation [15]. This catalyst stays active after several cycles of hydrogenation/dehydrogenation (Table 5 ). 2.1 Reaction mechanism We have tried to get mechanistic information on the direct carbon dioxide hydrogenation reaction, using the Fe(II)-PP3TS complex as catalyst. We have pressurized a 0.025 M catalyst (1) solution (in H2O and also in D2O) using medium pressure sapphire NMR tubes, up to 100 bar gas pressures (mixtures of CO2 and H2). Unfortunately, in the accessible temperature and pressure range in water (between 1 °C and 110 °C; and up to 100 bar – 50 bar of CO2 and 50 bar of H2 pressures), we have not get any signal, which could help to identify catalytically active species or intermediates in the 1H and 13C NMR spectra. In the 1H NMR spectra only the dissolved H2, the ligand protons, the formed formic acid and the water signal could be seen. In the 13C NMR, after taking a large number of scans, only the dissolved CO2, the resulting FA and the carbon atoms of the ligand could be detected. To identify the possible catalytically active species, hydrides, we have repeated the experiments with the catalyst (1) and only with pure H2 pressure. Pressurizing the Fe(II)-PP3TS catalyst solution (0.025 M) at 100 bar of H2, the solution shifted from purple to dark pink and one broad signal in the hydride region could be seen at around −10 ppm at 80 °C (Fig. 4 ). Cooling down gradually the sample lead to the formation of two broad signals, at around −8.2 and −13.5 ppm, the chemical shifts and integrals suggesting the ratio of the corresponding hydrogens of 2 to 1. Despite of our tentative and our efforts, these signals stayed broad and we could not get any further information for the multiplicities and couplings. Fortunately, a very similar system, the iron(II) with the same, but not sulfonated tripodal ligand, P(CH2CH2PPh2)3, PP3, has been studied in details by Bianchini and coworkers in acetone-d 6, allowing them to take the 1H NMR spectra down to – 85 °C [37,38]. At the temperature range of −10 °C K to +45 °C their 1H NMR spectra are very similar to our observations, showing the typical intramolecular exchange between of the coordinated dihydrogen and hydride. At lower temperatures they could see a well resolved multiplet (tdd) at - 12.47 ppm (intensity: 1 H), which was assigned to a terminal hydride which is coupled with the phosphorus nuclei of PP3. At −85 °C the resonance of the coordinated dihydrogen (intensity: 2 H) ligand started to broaden, but not resolved to give the possibility to determine the coupling constants. They have also detected the hydride – dihydrogen exchange. The same hydrido-dihydrogen complex has been identified by Beller and coworkers in the catalytic cycle during the formic acid dehydrogenation [14]. A very similar behavior was already described by Morris et al. for trans-[Fe(η2-H2)(H)(dppe)2]BF4 (dppe = PPh2CH2CH2PPh2) and for trans-[Ru(η2-H2)(H)(dppe)2]BF4 [15], giving further confirmation to our proposition. In order to determine the presence of a non-classical dihydrogen ligand, as well as to confirm the fast exchange between the hydride and the dihydrogen ligands, the respective T1 relaxation times were measured. The T1 value for the signal at −8.2 ppm (supposed to be a non-classical dihydrogen ligand) was found to be 30 ms while the relaxation time, T1 for the signal at −13.5 ppm (supposed to be a hydride ligand) was found to be 50 ms. Usually the T1 value for this latter one is somewhat longer, the determined value certainly short because of the intramolecular exchange [16,17]. 3 Conclusion We have shown that the direct homogeneous catalytic CO2 hydrogenation in aqueous solution, at room temperature, without any additives can be realized using the PP3TS ligand and iron(II) salts as catalyst precursors. The catalyst is robust and can be used for multiple cycles, its activity does not decrease after contact with air/oxygen. It has been shown that the temperature and the pressure are the key parameters and influence the synthetized final formic acid yield/concentration. This hydrogenation reaction is reversible in presence of the iron(II) – PP3TS catalyst, the equilibrium position, the direction of the reaction depends on the temperature and the H2 and CO2 pressures. Using this system, a charge/discharge hydrogen battery, a chemical hydrogen cylinder can be foreseen. The enthalpy of the formic acid formation and the activation energy for the carbon dioxide hydrogenation have been determined. 4 Experimental 4.1 General The air-sensitive compound (PP3) was manipulated under nitrogen atmosphere using standard Schlenk techniques. PP3 (97%) was purchased from Acros. All other reagents were commercially available and used as received. 4.2 NMR spectroscopy 1H, 13C and 31P NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker DRX-400 (5 mm) and Avance DRX-400 (10 mm) instruments. 3-(Trimethylsilyl)-1-propanesulfonic acid sodium salt (DSS) was used as an internal standard for 1H and 13C NMR experiments. For quantitative NMR measurements long acquisition delay times (D1 > 6 * T1) were used [18]. The spectra were processed with TopSpin, MestReNova and Igor Pro softwares. 4.3 PP3TS synthesis [15] The synthesis of the ligand was performed as described previously. A 3 L three-neck flask was equipped with a magnetic stirrer and charged with H2SO4 (98%, 56 mL, 1.05 mol), cooled to −10 °C by an ice-salt bath. PP3 (5g, 7.45 mmol) was slowly added over a 1 h period. After complete dissolution of the solid phosphine, oleum (65% SO3, 30 mL, 0.33 mol) was carefully added to the reaction mixture. The reaction mixture was allowed to warm to room temperature and stirred for 4 days. After this time the reaction was quenched with ice (100 g) and the mixture was neutralized over a 4 h period by adding NaOH (7M) with a dropping funnel. The water was removed under vacuum and MeOH (altogether 1 L) added to extract the sulfonated phosphine salt. The mixture was filtered under nitrogen and the filtrate reduced to dry, to afford 4.2 g (58%) of pure PP3TS as purple crystals. The 31P NMR spectrum of PP3TS displays one broad signal from −22.07 ppm to −18.26 ppm for the bridgehead phosphorous, while the diphenylphosphino groups gave rise to a broad signal from −15.52 to −11.54 ppm. Phosphine oxides were not observed during the synthesis in the 31P NMR spectra (30–80 ppm). The 1H NMR spectrum contains a broad resonance centred at 1.43 ppm for the three equivalent ethylene groups and several broad peaks between 6.22 and 8.44 ppm for the phenyl rings. The respective integral ratio was very near to 12:27, indicating that three phenyl groups were sulfonated. The negative mode ESI (electrospray ionization) MS corresponds to a trisulfonated salt (peaks at m/z = 302.98 for [M]3− and 465.72 for [M+Na]2−). Elemental analysis: expected C = 51.64% and H = 4.02% for C42H39Na3O9P4S3; obtained C = 51.64% and H = 4.01%. 5 Isochoric experiments In a typical experiment, PP3TS (0.0245 g, 0.025 mmol) was dissolved in water (2.0 mL) in a 10 mm NMR sapphire tube, and one equivalent of Fe(II) salt was added and dissolved (FeCl2, Fe(BF4)2 or (NH4)2Fe(SO4)2). The tube was then sealed and pressurized with CO2 and H2 (50–50 bar). The samples were continuously shaken with a rate of 200/min. This ensures the H2 and CO2 gas dissolution and saturation. Reactions were followed using quantitative 1H and 13C NMR by monitoring the formic acid peaks, relative to DSS standard. NMR spectra were taken upon defined interval (approximately every 4 h). When the integral of the formic acid peaks relative to the DSS remained identical (within 5% difference) after three subsequent measurements, equilibrium was believed to be reached, usually after ∼60 h at room temperature. 6 Recycling experiments A 10 mm sapphire NMR tube with the catalyst (0.025 M) was prepared as previously described, pressurized (50 bar CO2 and 50 bar H2), and shaked. Once equilibrium was reached, the pressure was release and the residual H2 and CO2 gases were vented. The open tube was thermostatted at 80 °C until no more formic acid could be detected in the solution by quantitative 1H and 13C NMR. The tube was then cooled back to room temperature and this process was repeated. coredata.dc:description: The negative consequences of the global warming require an important reduction of CO2 emission; and the valorization of the carbon dioxide, its transformation into useful chemicals is essential. We present here our studies on the direct CO2 hydrogenation reaction, yielding formic acid. In water, for the first time, an Fe(II) catalyst using meta-trisulfonated-tris[2-(diphenyl-phosphino)-ethyl]phosphine (PP3TS) ligand, has been found active in CO2 reduction. In homogeneous catalytic reactions, without any additives, at room temperature, under hydrogen and carbon dioxide gas pressures up to 0.5 M of formic acid is obtained, in acidic aqueous solutions. The same catalyst is active also in the reverse reaction, under different reaction conditions, i.e. at low pressure and high temperature. The CO2 reduction and formic acid dehydrogenation catalytic cycle has been repeated several times; without deactivation of the catalyst, it is not sensitive to oxygen/air. The Fe(II)-PP3TS complex could be a suitable catalyst in a chemical hydrogen storage/delivery system.
coredata.dc:title: Additive free, room temperature direct homogeneous catalytic carbon dioxide hydrogenation in aqueous solution using an iron(II) phosphine catalyst
